PreCam Science Case
PreCam Science Case

• Rich Kron has been working on the science case. He estimates that,
• Rich Kron has been working on the science case. He estimates that,

for the exposure times estimated to get to the magnitude limits proposed in the original PreCam document DES-doc-2374 (g,r,i,z,Y to 18.7, 18.3, 18.0, 17.3, 15.9), the PreCam Survey would take about twice as long as originally estimated in that document (96 nights vs. 47 nights). – Assumes larger between-field overlaps and takes into account various
for the exposure times estimated to get to the magnitude limits
proposed in the original PreCam document DES-doc-2374 (g,r,i,z,Y to
18.7, 18.3, 18.0, 17.3, 15.9), the PreCam Survey would take about
twice as long as originally estimated in that document (96 nights vs. 47
nights).
– Assumes larger between-field overlaps and takes into account various

overheads.
overheads.

• Douglas has been re-calculating the exposure times for PreCam and
• Douglas has been re-calculating the exposure times for PreCam and

also estimating the bright magnitude (saturation) limit for given PreCam exposure times.
also estimating the bright magnitude (saturation) limit for given
PreCam exposure times.

Discussion with Pat Seitzer (April 10)
Discussion with Pat Seitzer (April 10)

Douglas and Pat had a very productive discussion regarding PreCam and the Curtis-Schmidt on April 10. Among the issues discussed: •Pat clarified some misundertandings I had regarding making the official request to use the Curtis-Schmidt for PreCam. •Unfortunately, it won't be possible to use the Curtis-Schmidt in Dec 2009/Jan 2010 as we had originally hoped. •The current thinking is that DES could reasonably request 2 lunations -- in Dec 2010 and Jan 2011 -- plus a couple of weeks for an engineering/test run in July or Aug 2010. NASA would need to have "bump" privileges if an important event related to their program occurred during PreCam observing time. Furthermore, PreCam would need to take into account the 10% of observing time that is reserved for the Chilean astronomical community. •Pat provided several useful suggestions for Rich Kron's writeup of the PreCam science case. •There is currently no agreement between DES and Michigan for the use of the Curtis-Schmidt, but Michigan is willing to very seriously consider a request for telescope time.
Douglas and Pat had a very productive discussion regarding PreCam and the
Curtis-Schmidt on April 10. Among the issues discussed:
•Pat clarified some misundertandings I had regarding making the official request
to use the Curtis-Schmidt for PreCam.
•Unfortunately, it won't be possible to use the Curtis-Schmidt in Dec 2009/Jan
2010 as we had originally hoped.
•The current thinking is that DES could reasonably request 2 lunations -- in Dec
2010 and Jan 2011 -- plus a couple of weeks for an engineering/test run in July or
Aug 2010. NASA would need to have "bump" privileges if an important event
related to their program occurred during PreCam observing time. Furthermore,
PreCam would need to take into account the 10% of observing time that is
reserved for the Chilean astronomical community.
•Pat provided several useful suggestions for Rich Kron's writeup of the PreCam
science case.
•There is currently no agreement between DES and Michigan for the use of the
Curtis-Schmidt, but Michigan is willing to very seriously consider a request for
telescope time.
